Question:
What is the difference between the seven kinds of skillful observation and the three kinds of meanings?
Answer:
The seven kinds of skillful observation are without outflows, while the three kinds of meanings are with outflows.
Question:
If that is so, how can this be understood?
As it is said:
Correctly knowing form is the four knowledges, namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, etc., and conventional knowledge.
Answer:
Herein, the knowledge of enumeration operates on the object, but it is not necessarily all without outflows.
Question:
Can one observe the three kinds of meanings equally with the seven kinds of skillful means, and can one observe the seven kinds of skillful means equally with the three kinds of meanings?
Answer:
Some say it cannot.
Why is it so?
The seven kinds of skillful means are without outflows, while observing the three kinds of meanings has outflows.
Some say the seven kinds of skillful means have outflows and are without outflows, while observing the three kinds of meanings has outflows.
Question:

If that is so, can one observe the three kinds of meanings equally with the seven kinds of skillful means, and can one observe the seven kinds of skillful means equally with the three kinds of meanings?
Answer:
One can, but it requires much effort and much work. Truly knowing form up to consciousness, and truly knowing the faults of form up to consciousness, is called observing the aggregates.

To know as it truly is that form is arising, and so on up to knowing as it truly is that consciousness is arising, to know as it truly is that form is taste, and so on up to knowing as it truly is that consciousness is taste, this is said to be contemplation of the sense entrances.

To know as it truly is that form is cessation, and so on up to knowing as it truly is that consciousness is cessation, to know as it truly is that form is separation, and so on up to knowing as it truly is that consciousness is separation, this is said to be contemplation of the elements.
This can be said to be the same contemplation, but it requires more effort and more work.
Question:

The three kinds of contemplation come first, and the seven kinds of wholesome come later. Why did the World-Honored One first speak of the seven kinds of wholesome and later speak of the three kinds of contemplation?
Answer:
If it is said like this, then what is said accords with the meaning and is easy to understand, and the receiver is also easy.

Furthermore, what the World-Honored One says is complete in both text and meaning. If the three kinds of contemplation are spoken of first, although the meaning is complete, the text is not complete. The World-Honored One's teaching of the Dharma is complete in both text and meaning.
Furthermore, if it should be explained first, then the seven wholesome bases are explained first. If it should be explained later, then observing the three kinds of meanings is explained later.
Why is this?

Observing the three kinds of meanings may be at the beginning of the path of seeing, or at the beginning of the path of cultivation. Here, it is said to be at the beginning of the path of cultivation, but not at the beginning of the path of seeing.
Just as the path of seeing and the path of cultivation, the stage of seeing and the stage of cultivation, and the faculty of wanting to know, the faculty of knowing, are also like this.

Furthermore, observing the three kinds of meanings may be at the beginning of the noble path in six stages, or at the beginning of the noble path in nine stages. Here, it is said to be in the beginning of the nine stages, but not in the beginning of the six stages.
The Venerable Vasumitra said:
Here, four kinds of stages are explained, namely the stage of practice, the stage of seeing, the stage of cultivation, and the stage of no more learning.
As it is said:
Monks, being good in seven ways, observes the three kinds of meanings.
This is said to be the stage of practice.

To know form as it really is is to speak of the path of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, up to knowing consciousness as it really is is to speak of the path of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, which is called the stage of seeing.
To contemplate form up to consciousness as having taste, danger, and separation is called the stage of cultivation.
To quickly attain the exhaustion of defilements in this Dharma is called the stage of no more learning.
Question:
If that is so, why are four wholesome bases spoken of in the path of seeing, and three wholesome bases spoken of in the path of cultivation?
Answer:
In the path of seeing, one sees truths that have never been seen before, while in the path of cultivation, one sees truths that have already been seen.

Furthermore, in the path of seeing, one attains the contemplation of truths with the noble nature that has never been attained before, while in the path of cultivation, one contemplates truths with the noble nature that has already been attained.
Question:
Why is the truth of the path spoken of only once here, while the other three truths are spoken of twice?
Answer:
Here, the truth of the path is spoken of extensively.
As it is said:
To know form as it really is as suffering is the truth of the path.
To know form as it really is as arising, ceasing, the path, taste, danger, and escape, up to knowing consciousness in the same way, is the truth of the path.
Furthermore, what is said here is for those who have already seen the truth.
The Buddha said:
If you can contemplate the aggregates as they really are, you will soon be able to end your defilements.
Furthermore, the three truths are limited dharmas.
As it is said:
The limit of the five appropriated aggregates, the limit of the arising of the five appropriated aggregates, the limit of the cessation of the five appropriated aggregates.
Question:
If so, then one question leads to another.
Why are the three truths said to have limits, but the truth of the path is not said to have limits?
Answer:
The meaning of limit here is explained in detail in the section on the knowledge of the limits of seeing the path, etc.

Furthermore, there is suffering that has already arisen and suffering that has not yet arisen, there are causes of suffering that have already arisen and causes of suffering that have not yet arisen, there is cessation of suffering that has already arisen and cessation of suffering that has not yet arisen.

Who can know, cut off, and realize the suffering that has already arisen, the suffering that has not yet arisen, the causes of suffering that have already arisen, the causes of suffering that have not yet arisen, the cessation of suffering that has already arisen, and the cessation of suffering that has not yet arisen?
It is the truth of the path.
Question:
Why did the World-Honored One extensively distinguish what is to be known by wisdom?
Answer:
In order to cause those who have lost the path to return to the path, he spoke in this way.
Moreover, what is said here is for those who practice with craving. The Buddha said:
You should contemplate the flavor and faults of these aggregates. If you see the flavor and faults of these aggregates, you will soon be able to exhaust the defilements.
Question:

Why is it that in the path of seeing, one first contemplates suffering and then contemplates its origin, while in the path of cultivation, one first contemplates its origin and then contemplates suffering?
Answer:
There are two kinds of accordance: first, accordance with the path of seeing, and second, accordance with what is said.
According to accordance with the path of seeing, one first contemplates suffering and then contemplates its origin;
As explained, first observe the accumulation and then observe suffering.
The sequence in which the path of seeing is explained is also like this.
Question:
What is the difference between the accumulation of form and the taste of form?
Answer:
The name itself is the difference. This is called the accumulation of form, and this is called the taste of form.
Furthermore, the accumulation of form belongs to the mental realm, while the taste of form is common to the six consciousnesses.
Furthermore, the accumulation is defiled and undefiled, while the taste is defiled.
Furthermore, the accumulation is in the three realms, while the taste is in the desire realm.
Question:
Are there many kinds of accumulation of the aggregates or is there one kind of accumulation?
If there are many kinds of accumulation, how can the Sutra of Exposition be understood?
As it is said:
This craving is the cause, root, and condition of suffering in the past, future, and present.
If there is one kind, how can this sutra be understood?
As it is said:

The accumulation of joy and love is the accumulation of form, the accumulation of contact is the accumulation of the three aggregates, and the accumulation of name and form is the accumulation of consciousness.
Answer:
It should be said:
There are reasons for multiple accumulations, and there are reasons for a single accumulation.
Because it explains proximate causes, it is multiple accumulations;
Because it explains distant causes, it is a single accumulation.
Just as there are proximate causes and distant causes, the same is true for one's own body and others' bodies.
Furthermore, here three kinds of accumulations are explained: first, the accumulation of afflictions, second, the accumulation of suffering, and third, the accumulation of karma.
The accumulation of joy and love and the accumulation of form are explained as the accumulation of afflictions;
The accumulation of contact and the accumulation of the three aggregates are explained as the accumulation of suffering;
The accumulation of name and form and the accumulation of consciousness are explained as the accumulation of karma.
Here, name and form are explained as karma.

Just as with the accumulation of afflictions, the accumulation of suffering, and the accumulation of karma, there is the path of afflictions, the path of suffering, and the path of karma. The afflictions, suffering, and karma should be understood in the same way.
Furthermore, here three times are mentioned, namely the time of accumulation, the time of enjoyment, and the time of protection.

The accumulation of joy and love and the accumulation of form are said to be the time of accumulation, the accumulation of contact and the accumulation of the three aggregates are said to be the time of enjoyment, and the accumulation of name and form and the accumulation of consciousness are said to be the time of protection.
Furthermore, here three times of existence are mentioned, namely the existence of the past, the intermediate existence, and the existence of birth.

The accumulation of joy and love and the accumulation of form are said to be the existence of the past, the accumulation of contact and the accumulation of the three aggregates are said to be the intermediate existence, and the accumulation of name and form and the accumulation of consciousness are said to be the existence of birth.

Furthermore, the accumulation of joy and love and the accumulation of form are said to be the condition of name and form, the accumulation of contact and the accumulation of the three aggregates are said to be the condition of name, and the accumulation of name and form and the accumulation of consciousness are said to be the condition of name and form.
Furthermore, love seeks future existence, therefore the Buddha said:
The accumulation of joy and love is the accumulation of form.
The mind and mental factors live through contact and arise from contact, by the power of contact they are able to appear in the present, the Buddha said:
The arising of contact is the arising of the three aggregates.
Consciousness is established based on name-and-form and becomes extensive. Therefore, the Buddha said:
The arising of name-and-form is the arising of consciousness.
Question:
What is the difference between the cessation of form and the separation from form?
Answer:
If craving creates this form, when that craving ceases, it is called the cessation of form.
If other craving arises based on this form, when that craving is separated, it is called the separation from form, and so on in detail.
Question:
Why is the cessation of form answered by the cessation of craving?
Answer:
When the cause is cut off, the effect is also cut off.
When the cause ceases, the effect also ceases.
Abandoning the cause also abandons the effect, vomiting the cause also vomits the effect, and destroying the cause also destroys the effect.
Question:
Why is the cessation of craving said for what has already arisen, and separation from craving said for what has not yet arisen?
Answer:
What has already arisen cannot be made into what has not yet arisen. The Buddha said:
One should only extinguish it.
Unarisen love should be prevented from arising, one should only be separated from it.
Thus there are three kinds of calamities: one already experienced, one being experienced, and one to be experienced.
The already experienced is that which has been experienced, the presently experienced is that which is being endured.
The to-be-experienced is that which, either by one's own power or the power of one's dependents or the power of wealth, seeks to be separated from by means of skillful means.
It is also like this.

Question:
Why is love mentioned three times here, but the other afflictions and karma are not mentioned?
Answer:
Because love is a grave calamity that is difficult to cut off and difficult to remove, it is explained in detail as above.
In this way, the Sutra of Exposition extensively distinguishes the truth of cessation.
